General context and content of the dossier  3.1 Introductory overview    The declared main objective of the current proposal for an EU AI Act is to create the conditions for anecosystem of trust regarding the placing on the market, putting into service and use of AI in the EU.    The AI Regulation will specifically apply to:    - providers that place AI systems on the market or put

the dominant position of these incumbents.    3.3.6 The compliance cost caused by new regulation may significantly inhibit the diffusion anduptake of new technologies classified as AI-systems.    3.3.7 It can be concluded that the proposed EU AI Act creates a considerable regulatory burden,which may weaken the competitive position of SMEs in the area of AI systems andpotentially result in disincentives for innovation. highlights.text: machinesremain machines and people must be able to retain control over them.    The proposed Regulation on AI, also known as the AI Act, is a first of its kind in theworld and will have a massive impact on the development, deployment and use of AI.The EESC welcomes this proposal and is pleased that health, safety and fundamentalrights are at its heart. Even though the AI Act raises the bar substantially as regards thequality, performance and trustworthiness of AI that the EU is willing to allow, there are

recognition in publicly and privately accessible spaces and is calling for a ban of thesepractices, which are extremely invasive, lack any sound scientific basis and posesubstantial risks of harm to a number of fundamental rights. Last but not least, the AIAct should provide for certain decisions to remain the prerogative of humans,particularly in domains where these decisions have a moral component and legalimplications or a societal impact. The Declaration on DigitalRights and Principles provides a clear reference point for policy makers, as well as companiesand experts, when making their assessments.    With the AI Act, the EU is pioneering a regulation to mitigate the threats posed by AIand algorithmic systems and ensure that high-risk AI systems are designed, deployed andused in full consideration and respect of fundamental rights and democratic values. highlights.text: activities,reducing the overall time spent on customs processes and accordingly the consumption ofresources.    The proposal is driven by the digital by default and privacy by default principles. It alignswith flagship Commission initiatives such as the AI act, Data Governance Act, GDPR andEUDPR. It provides for user-centric processes ready for automation, enabling all operationalexchanges with customs to be carried out electronically through a single multipurpose EUinterface. It supports the once-only principle
